title: Sets and Mappings
description: Fundamental concepts of set theory and mappings between sets.
markdownContent:
ðŸ“˜ Sets and Mappings

1. Basic Concepts of Set Theory

A set is a collection of certain, well-distinguished objects to form a whole - Georg Cantor, 1895.

Important Properties:

  • Each object either belongs to the set or not
  • The order of elements is unimportant
  • Each element appears only once

Examples:

  • Set of natural numbers: $\mathbb{N} = \{1, 2, 3, \dots\}$
  • Set of integers: $\mathbb{Z} = \{\dots, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, \dots\}$
  • Set of rational numbers: $\mathbb{Q} = \left\{ \frac{p}{q} \mid p \in \mathbb{Z}, q \in \mathbb{N} \right\}$
  • Set of real numbers: $\mathbb{R}$

2. Set Operations

Union

$$A \cup B = \{ x \mid x \in A \text{ or } x \in B \}$$

The union contains all elements that appear in A or B.

Intersection

$$A \cap B = \{ x \mid x \in A \text{ and } x \in B \}$$

The intersection contains only the elements that appear in both sets.

Difference

$$A \setminus B = \{ x \in A \mid x \notin B \}$$

The difference contains the elements of A that do not appear in B.

Complement

$$A^c = \{ x \mid x \notin A \}$$

The complement contains all elements that do not appear in A.

3. Relationships Between Sets

Subset

$$A \subseteq B \Leftrightarrow \forall x \in A: x \in B$$

A is a subset of B if every element of A is also contained in B.

Proper Subset

$$A \subset B \Leftrightarrow A \subseteq B \text{ and } A \neq B$$

A is a proper subset of B if A is a subset of B and A is not equal to B.

Equality

$$A = B \Leftrightarrow A \subseteq B \text{ and } B \subseteq A$$

Two sets are equal if they contain the same elements.

4. Important Sets

Empty Set

$$\emptyset = \{ \}$$

The set without elements.

Power Set

$$\mathcal{P}(A) = \{ X \mid X \subseteq A \}$$

The set of all subsets of A.

Cartesian Product

$$A \times B = \{ (a,b) \mid a \in A, b \in B \}$$

The set of all ordered pairs (a,b) with a from A and b from B.

5. Mappings Between Sets

Definition of a Mapping

$$f: A \to B$$

A mapping $f$ from $A$ to $B$ assigns to each element $a \in A$ exactly one element $b \in B$.

Properties of Mappings

  • Injective: $\forall a_1, a_2 \in A: f(a_1) = f(a_2) \Rightarrow a_1 = a_2$
  • Surjective: $\forall b \in B \exists a \in A: f(a) = b$
  • Bijective: injective and surjective

Composition of Mappings

$$(g \circ f)(x) = g(f(x))$$

The composition of two mappings $f: A \to B$ and $g: B \to C$ is a new mapping $g \circ f: A \to C$.

Inverse Mapping

$$f^{-1}: B \to A$$

The inverse mapping $f^{-1}$ exists if and only if $f$ is bijective.

6. Important Mappings

Identity Mapping

$$\text{id}_A: A \to A, \quad \text{id}_A(a) = a$$

The identity mapping maps each element to itself.

Constant Mapping

$$f: A \to B, \quad f(a) = b_0 \text{ for all } a \in A$$

A constant mapping maps all elements to the same value.

Restriction of a Mapping

$$f|_C: C \to B, \quad f|_C(c) = f(c) \text{ for } C \subseteq A$$

The restriction of a mapping to a subset of the domain.
